annotation.TEXT: Air Man also has one of the highest jumps in the game (second only to Quick Man). Beyond that, he can't really do much else. I would probably use him more often if he had more all-around traits (such as being able to climb ladders). And on that note: I know he has a bulkier frame than most of the other MM2 Robot Masters, but if Crash Man can climb ladders, why can't Air Man?

Although it's obviously possible to do this section with Heat Man, I couldn't help but abuse Quick Man's higher jumps here (if mostly to cut down on what would likely be the constant sound of Heat Man's charging effect).

Just to note: You can only hold 3 E-Tanks at any given time in this game. If you come into contact with one while you have the maximum amount, you won't be able pick it up until you have less than 3 in your inventory screen. It's a very welcome idea that prevents wasting tanks (along with potentially serving as a free health pick-up if you use it right, as seen here).

Air Man somewhat falls into the same category as Bubble Man and Flash Man: useful, but rather situational. This mainly due to his method of attack. The Air Shooter fires in a continuous cluster at an upwards angle, along with causing a draft that pushes nearly every enemy in the direction you're firing. Given the obvious however, it can be somewhat difficult to hit anything with it (granted though, a lot of the enemies in this stage are positioned above you).

It's also worth noting that you're completely invincible while dashing as well. While this is generally used to get extra height for jumps or bypassing certain hazards, it can also be used as an attack (though it lasts for only a brief moment, so it should only be used on enemies you're certain won't hit you once the dash stops).

Heat Man is yet another Robot Master that falls directly into the "middle ground" category. He has average jump height and can't climb ladders (for whatever reason). The Atomic Fire functions like his original projectiles, which fire out in two shots at set arcs. Heat Man's real unique trait however, comes in the form of his charge ability. Holding down the fire button builds up your charge, which when released, sends you briefly dashing in whatever direction you're holding.

Magnet Man now has different phases to his fight. He'll follow a similar pattern at first (although he now only jumps to the opposite ends of the screen during his first phase), but afterwards, the new magnets embedded in his room's ceiling will turn on and pull you up. If you happen to have Wood Man, you can completely cheese this fight (since he's both immune to the magnetic pull and serves as the weakness to Magnet Man). Even though I won't be doing so however, this fight is still pretty simple once you get the overall pattern down.

Snake Man is a bit awkward to fight (if you plan on using Air Man all the way through, or if he's the only RM you have on-hand). Although Snake Man's pattern is virtually unchanged, his room has two of those blocks from before that you can push with the Air Shooter, which can potentially throw things off and make maneuvering a bit more hectic than usual. Before anyone asks however: To my knowledge, it's not possible to crush Snake Man with these blocks (although it could be possible to crush yourself by accident).
